title: Synthetic Recap
body:
LOS ANGELES — On a night where the Boston Celtics’ legends battled valiantly, the Great Western Forum belonged to one man, and one man alone. Shaquille O’Neal delivered a performance of raw, unstoppable force, pouring in a career-high 46 points to power the Los Angeles Lakers to a thrilling 109-102 victory over their archrivals.

From the opening tip, this was a clash of titans. Boston’s Antoine Walker answered the bell with a brilliant 30-point, 15-reouble double, while Rick Pitino’s Celtics fought with the pride their storied franchise demands. But they had no answer for the diesel engine in the middle of the paint. O’Neal was a wrecking ball, dominating the interior with an array of powerful dunks and soft-touch finishes, pulling down 13 rebounds to complete his own mighty double-double.

The Celtics, led by Walker’s sharpshooting and Dee Brown’s 20 points, hung tight throughout the contest, refusing to let the Lakers pull away. But every time Boston threatened, the Lakers went back to their bedrock: feed the big fella. Shaq’s sheer physicality overwhelmed every defender sent his way.

While Nick Van Exel’s 20 points provided crucial support, this night was not about a supporting cast. It was a historic, career-defining eruption from the most dominant force in the game. Shaq’s 46 points were a statement, a herculean effort that carved a victory from the heat of battle against the Lakers’ most hated foe. On this night, the legacy of the Celtics-Lakers rivalry found a new, singular protagonist wearing Forum blue and gold.
